reasoning: Running is a repetitive locomotor gait cycle composed primarily of sagittal-plane hip, knee and ankle flexion–extension producing forward progression. Primary joint actions are hip extension during push-off and hip flexion during swing, knee extension at stance-to-push-off and knee flexion during swing, and ankle plantarflexion at toe-off with dorsiflexion during swing. Single-leg support phases require frontal-plane hip abductor stabilization and transverse-plane pelvic/trunk rotation for counterbalance; arm swing involves shoulder flexion/extension and elbow flexion/extension as secondary, coordinated movements. Muscles produce concentric/isometric actions for propulsion (glutes, quads, calves) and eccentric control (hamstrings, tibialis anterior), while core and hip abductors stabilize the pelvis and spine.

joint_actions.action: isometric abduction/adduction control during single-leg stance
alternating flexion/extension and elbow flexion/extension with arm swing

notes: Variations (sprint, uphill, trail) increase force demands and hip/ankle power. Running is primarily locomotion; if carrying load or performing heavily asymmetrical arm actions, add CARRY or ANTI_ROTATION as applicable.

reasoning: A long-distance run is a repetitive bipedal locomotion task. Primary joint actions are cyclical sagittal-plane hip flexion and extension, knee flexion and extension, and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion to produce stride and propulsion. During single-leg stance phases the hip abductors and core provide frontal- and transverse-plane stabilization and the trunk undergoes counter-rotation with the pelvis; the shoulders and elbows perform reciprocal arm swing but are secondary to lower‑limb locomotor mechanics. Stabilization demands include single‑leg balance, shock attenuation at the ankle/knee/hip, and isometric/isodirectional core control to resist excessive rotation and maintain posture over many repetitive cycles.
notes: Endurance, impact and surface (road, trail) alter loading and stabilization demands. Faster running or sprinting increases hip extension power and may accentuate transverse-plane demands; carrying loads or asymmetrical implements would add CARRY/ANTI_ROTATION elements.

reasoning: Running is a locomotion pattern driven by cyclic sagittal-plane lower‑limb actions producing forward propulsion. The primary propulsive phase uses hip extension, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion (stance push-off) while recovery involves hip and knee flexion and ankle dorsiflexion. Arm swing (shoulder flexion/extension) and trunk rotation occur as coordinated transverse/sagittal components. Stabilization demands single‑leg balance (frontal plane hip abduction control) and core isometric control to transfer forces and resist excess rotation.
notes: Intensity/grade/footwear alter emphasis (sprinting/incline increases hip extensor and plantarflexor demand; barefoot shifts more distal loading). Uneven surfaces and fatigue increase frontal/transverse stabilization demands.

reasoning: This is a walking/gait task: primary joint actions are repeated hip flexion and extension, knee flexion and extension, and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion in the sagittal plane. Hip extensors (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) and hip flexors (iliopsoas) drive pendular leg action, quadriceps control knee extension during stance, and plantarflexors (gastrocnemius/soleus) produce push-off while tibialis anterior controls foot clearance. The trunk and pelvic musculature (erector spinae, obliques, gluteus medius) act isometrically or eccentrically to stabilize the spine and resist frontal/transverse plane perturbations during single‑leg stance. As a bodyweight recovery walk there is minimal loading or intentional rotation/anti-rotation, so the primary pattern is locomotion.
notes: Recovery pace walking — low intensity, primarily steady-state locomotion. Variations (incline, loaded, uneven terrain) would add HINGE/CARRY/ANTI_ROTATION or greater transverse/frontal demands.

reasoning: Running is cyclic bipedal locomotion driven primarily by repeated hip, knee and ankle motion in the sagittal plane. Primary joint actions: hip extension during push-off and hip flexion during swing; knee extension in stance and knee flexion in swing; ankle plantarflexion for propulsion and dorsiflexion during swing/foot clearance. The pelvis and trunk exhibit transverse counter-rotation and the arms swing (shoulder/elbow sagittal motion) as accessory motions. Single-leg stance phases require frontal-plane hip stabilization and core control to maintain alignment. Muscles producing the movement are the posterior chain (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) for propulsion, quadriceps for knee control in stance, calf complex (gastrocnemius/soleus) for push-off, tibialis anterior for dorsiflexion/foot clearance, hip flexors (iliopsoas) for swing, and gluteus medius plus core musculature for frontal-plane and rotational stability.
notes: Warm-up jogging at steady pace is textbook LOCOMOTION. Variations (sprints, uphill, loaded runs) change muscle emphasis and may increase anti-rotation/hip abductor demand. High-impact considerations: foot strike, cadence, and single-leg loading require attention to joint loading and progression.

reasoning: A 1-mile walk is a locomotor gait task. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: hip flexion during swing and hip extension during stance; knee flexion during swing and knee extension during stance; ankle dorsiflexion for foot clearance and plantarflexion for push-off. There is also transverse plane pelvic/trunk rotation and frontal plane hip abduction/adduction activity for pelvic stabilization during single-leg support. Primary movers (gluteus maximus, hamstrings, quadriceps, gastrocnemius/soleus, tibialis anterior, iliopsoas) produce the cyclical flexion/extension actions while gluteus medius and core muscles isometrically stabilize the pelvis and trunk. Arm/shoulder reciprocal swing (shoulder flexion/extension) provides counterbalance but is secondary to lower-limb locomotion.

joint_actions.action: axial rotation (reciprocal pelvic and trunk rotation)
abduction/adduction to control pelvic drop during single-leg support

notes: Unloaded, level walking is pure LOCOMOTION. Variations (speed, incline, carrying a load, asymmetry) would add patterns such as CARRY or ANTI_ROTATION and increase posterior chain demand.

exercise: 30 sec static hold with 70 lb sand duffel
reasoning: This is an isometric loaded-hold in an anterior/bear-hug position. Primary mechanical demand is maintaining a loaded position against gravity (carry pattern) with minimal joint motion. The shoulders are held in flexion and adduction to cradle the bag, elbows are flexed isometrically, and the spine resists forward-flexion (isometric spinal extension/anti-flexion). Hips, knees and ankles are held in near-neutral/stable extension to support posture. Muscles produce isometric force to support the load and control breathing; if performed unilaterally or with gait it would add clear anti-rotation and locomotion demands.
primary_muscles: gluteus maximus and hamstrings (postural hip stability)
notes: Classification assumes a bilateral anterior/bear-hug static hold. If held asymmetrically (single-arm or suitcase) add ANTI_ROTATION. If performed while walking/marching, include LOCOMOTION/CARRY as dynamic carry. Front-rack vs bear-hug slightly changes shoulder/pectoral emphasis but remains a carry-style isometric pattern.

exercise: 5-Minute Calisthenics Warm-Up (jumping jacks, bodyweight squats, inchworms)
reasoning: This warm-up is a composite of several movement patterns. Bodyweight squats are primary sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion/extension under a vertical torso (SQUAT). Inchworms require dynamic hip flexion to fold forward and controlled hip extension/shoulder-supported progression into a plank and back, emphasizing a hip hinge-like pattern and core stabilization (HINGE). Jumping jacks are a bilateral, rhythmic jumping/gating drill that uses coordinated lower-extensor chain extension and frontal-plane shoulder and hip ab/adduction — functionally a locomotor/plyometric warm-up movement (LOCOMOTION). Primary movers are prioritized (hips/knees for squat, hips/posterior chain for inchworm hinge, lower-extensor chain and deltoids for jumping jacks) with secondary demands on the core and scapular stabilizers for posture and transition control.
notes: This is a mixed warm-up combining mobility, activation and light plyometrics. Intensity, range of motion, and exercise selection can be scaled for beginners or those with shoulder/knee restrictions (e.g., step-touch instead of jumping jacks, partial squats, walk hands to elevated surface for inchworms). No significant rotational or loaded carry demands in standard versions.

reasoning: Primary movement is trunk (spine) flexion in the sagittal plane as the torso is brought toward the pelvis — functionally a concentric 'pulling' of the ribcage toward the pelvis. Secondary hip flexion often contributes (iliopsoas/rectus femoris) especially if feet are anchored or the motion is taken higher. Stabilization demands include isometric activation of the posterior chain (erector spinae) to control descent and pelvic stabilizers to limit unwanted hip-dominant motion. No primary frontal or transverse plane rotation is required for the standard 3/4 sit-up.
notes: If feet are anchored or the torso rises higher, hip flexor contribution increases and the pattern becomes more hip-dominant. A pure curl-up (thoracic flexion only) would emphasize rectus abdominis with less hip flexor involvement. No rotational or anti-rotation pattern unless performed with added twist or asymmetric load.

reasoning: This is primarily a hamstring-focused mobility/stretch that lengthens the posterior thigh by extending the knee while the hip is held in ~90° flexion. The primary moving joint is the knee (extension in the sagittal plane); the hip is maintained in flexion isometrically to bias the hamstrings. Quadriceps (especially rectus femoris) produce/permit knee extension (can be active or passive), while the hamstrings are the lengthened/target tissue. Pelvic and spinal musculature act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and maintain neutral spine during the motion. Although not a classical HINGE-based load-transfer (hip-dominant) exercise, the posterior chain focus and sagittal-plane knee/hip relationship makes HINGE the closest available pattern.
notes: Primarily a mobility/stretch exercise rather than a load-transfer pattern. Can be performed passively (assisted) or actively (eccentric control by hamstrings/active knee extension by quads). If classifying by strict joint action, this is a single-joint knee-dominant movement; no major transverse or frontal plane components. Manual review recommended if strict pattern-matching is required.

exercise: 7-strike combo (jab → rear cross → rear upper → lead upper → rear body hook → lead body hook → lead cross)
reasoning: This striking combo is primarily a series of rapid pushing actions of the upper limb (shoulder horizontal adduction/protraction with elbow extension) delivered in the transverse plane. Power is generated and transmitted through sequential axial rotation of the trunk and hips (transverse plane) with lower‑limb weight transfer and brief sagittal plane extension at the hip/knee. Primary movers are the pecs/ant deltoid/triceps for the punch (push) and the obliques/other trunk rotators and hip rotators/glutes for generating and transferring rotational torque. Stabilization demands include scapular control (serratus anterior, lower trap) for protraction/retraction and anti‑flexion/anti‑extension/isometric core control to decelerate and link segmental force; single‑sided punches also impose anti‑rotation/isometric bracing on contralateral core musculature.
notes: Primary classification is horizontal/forward push actions combined with trunk/hip rotation. Depending on stance and footwork (stepping or pivoting) rotational and lower‑limb contributions may increase; unilateral striking increases anti‑rotation stabilization demands and scapular stabilizer load. Using mitts, resistance bands, or weighted gloves can increase PUSH or ANTI_ROTATION emphasis.

reasoning: This finisher is a bodyweight, play-based conditioning activity that primarily consists of dynamic moving (running, sprinting, jogging, skipping, directional changes) — i.e., locomotion. Primary joint actions are repeated hip, knee and ankle sagittal-plane flexion/extension producing gait and propulsion. Secondary multi‑planar actions include trunk and shoulder rotation during changes of direction, reaching, throwing/catching and arm swing, so ROTATION is included. Stabilization demands are high: the lumbopelvic core and hip abductors/adductors act isometrically to control frontal/transverse plane forces during cuts and single‑leg support, while scapular stabilizers control arm actions.
notes: Highly variable, multi‑directional session — specifics depend on the exact activities in the finisher (e.g., more jumping would add SQUAT/PLYOMETRY; added carrying would include CARRY). Classification assumes primarily locomotor play with frequent rotational/turning demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane spinal flexion (trunk curl) produced by concentric shortening of the anterior trunk musculature. The spine (lumbar and thoracic segments) performs flexion while the pelvis/hips are typically stabilized against the machine's pad; depending on machine geometry there may be minimal hip movement or posterior pelvic tilt. Stabilization is required from the posterior chain (erector spinae) eccentrically and the deep core (transverse abdominis) isometrically to control spinal position. Chosen pattern: ROTATION is the closest available classification in the provided list, but mechanically this is a spinal-flexion (trunk-curl) dominant exercise in the sagittal plane rather than an axial rotation or anti-rotation task.

exercise: Abs Flow (5 V-ups → 5 hollow rocks, repeat)
reasoning: Primary movement is dynamic sagittal-plane trunk and hip flexion (V-ups) combined with an anti‑extension/controlled hollow position (hollow rocks). The V-up phase actively shortens the rectus abdominis and hip flexors to bring torso and legs together (spinal flexion + hip flexion in the sagittal plane). The hollow rock emphasizes isometric anterior core control to resist lumbar extension (anti‑extension) and maintain a rigid torso while rocking. Secondary stabilization includes pelvic control and transient shoulder/upper‑torso flexion to assist reaching in V-ups; scapular/shoulder stability is minimal. Because the sequence alternates between active sagittal flexion and an isometric anti‑extension demand, the primary pattern best classified is an anti‑rotation/anti‑movement core stability category (closest available label: ANTI_ROTATION).
notes: No external load; primarily a core (anterior chain) exercise. Could be paired with canonical 'core flexion' label if available. Progressions: weighted V-ups, toes-to-bar; regressions: bent‑knee V-ups, dead bug for anti‑extension focus.

reasoning: Primary movement at the glenohumeral joint is shoulder flexion in the sagittal plane as the hands/roller move anteriorly. The lumbar spine moves into relative extension during the rollout and is actively resisted (anti‑extension) by the anterior core; on the return the rectus abdominis and obliques produce spinal flexion to bring the torso back. Scapular protraction/stabilization and maintained elbow extension are required. Thus the dominant external action is a horizontal/anti‑extension 'push' pattern driven by shoulder flexion and core control; the exercise emphasizes resisting spinal extension rather than producing rotation.
notes: Though primarily classified here as a PUSH pattern (horizontal push/anti‑extension), the exercise is fundamentally an anti‑extension core exercise. Variations (kneeling vs standing) change lever arm and difficulty; asymmetric or single‑arm rollouts introduce anti‑rotation/anti‑lateral flexion demands.

reasoning: Primary action is a controlled vertical pull of the shoulder girdle: the scapulothoracic joints perform depression and retraction while the glenohumeral joints are held in slight extension; elbows are largely isometric (holding) and the spine is held neutral. This is predominantly a pulling/scapular-control pattern rather than a pushing, locomotion, or carry pattern. Stabilization demands include rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers to keep the humeral head centered and prevent excessive shoulder elevation or protraction, plus grip muscles to maintain the hang and core to limit swing.

joint_actions.action: scapular depression and retraction (scapulothoracic), slight glenohumeral extension

notes: Tabata alternation (active hang vs dead hang or brief rests) increases time under tension and grip fatigue. Emphasize scapular control to avoid impingement; progress toward active scapular pull-ups for concentric strength. No primary hip/knee/ankle involvement.

reasoning: An active deadhang is an isometric overhead hanging position where the upper limb musculature produces sustained pulling force to support body weight. Primary joint actions are scapular depression and retraction (shoulder girdle) with the glenohumeral joint held in overhead flexion; the elbows are extended and held isometrically. This places demand on the latissimus dorsi/teres major and scapular stabilizers (lower trapezius, rhomboids) to maintain a depressed/retracted scapular position while forearm/finger flexors sustain grip. The core and shoulder rotator cuff act isometrically to stabilize the spine and glenohumeral joint and reduce swing.
notes: Active deadhang is primarily an isometric upper-body pull/stability pattern emphasizing scapular control and grip endurance. Variations (scapular shrugs, active retraction vs passive hang, single-arm hangs, or adding leg/knee raises) change classification — single-arm variations introduce significant anti-rotation demands and would warrant ANTI_ROTATION in addition to PULL. Progressions can lead toward dynamic PULL movements (pull-ups). Ensure scapular engagement to protect the glenohumeral joint.

reasoning: The common adductor stretch performed as a lateral/side lunge style stretch primarily uses frontal-plane hip motion similar to a lateral lunge: the working hip moves into abduction on the unloaded side while the loaded side adopts hip adduction and knee flexion to lower into the stretch. Primary joint actions are frontal-plane hip abduction/adduction with accompanying sagittal-plane knee flexion and ankle dorsiflexion. The adductor muscle group (adductor longus/brevis/magnus, gracilis, pectineus) is the tissue lengthened/stretched; gluteal muscles and quadriceps act eccentrically/isometrically to control the descent and stabilize the pelvis. Core and ankle stabilizers maintain upright posture and frontal-plane balance.
notes: Classification assumes a lateral/side-lunge style adductor stretch. If the adductor stretch is performed as a seated butterfly, straddle/split passive stretch, or supine mobilization, the movement pattern relevance to LUNGE is reduced and classification is more of a mobility/stretch than a functional loading pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is a loaded hip hinge with trunk lateral flexion and rotation while a single arm holds a kettlebell overhead. The hips flex/hinge (sagittal) to lower the torso toward the front/side leg while the thoracic spine rotates and laterally flexes (transverse and frontal) to clear the torso under the load. The overhead shoulder/arm acts isometrically to stabilize the load and resist transverse plane torque (anti-rotation) produced by the rotating/laterally flexing trunk. Posterior chain (gluteus maximus/hamstrings) produces the hip hinge; obliques, erector spinae and quadratus lumborum control lateral flexion; transverse rotation is produced/controlled by obliques and multifidus; deltoids/rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers maintain the overhead position. Secondary requirements include single-leg/hip stability (glute medius) and knee/ankle stabilization during a loaded unilateral stance.
notes: High mobility and stability demands: thoracic rotation, hamstring length, and shoulder stability are limiting factors. Variations include bottom-up kettlebell for greater anti-rotation demand, strict (longer leg) or split-stance versions for different stability emphases. Take care with lumbar loading; progressive loading and technique coaching recommended.

reasoning: Adductor/groin stretches are most commonly performed as lateral/side-lunge or seated butterfly variations that primarily place length on the hip adductors by moving the femur into relative abduction (frontal plane) with associated hip external rotation (transverse). When performed as a standing side-lunge/cossack the primary joint excursions are at the hip (frontal/transverse) and knee (sagittal) on the working limb; the movement pattern therefore corresponds most closely to a lateral lunge/lunge family movement. The adductors (being stretched) are the primary tissues of interest, hip abductors (gluteus medius/minimus) and quadriceps control the motion into/out of the position, and the trunk/obliques maintain upright posture isometrically.

joint_actions.action: abduction (relative movement to lengthen adductors) with external rotation component
flexion (on the loaded/weighted side in side-lunge variants)

notes: If performed as a seated butterfly (soles together) the dominant joint actions are hip external rotation and mild abduction in a non-weightbearing context; if done as a standing side-lunge/cossack the LUNGE classification is more directly appropriate. For purely passive/assisted stretching the movement is low-load and largely passive but mechanics remain the same.

reasoning: Assuming the bodyweight 'air bike' (bicycle crunch) performed supine: primary action is trunk rotation combined with trunk flexion and reciprocal hip flexion as each elbow moves toward the opposite knee. The spine undergoes flexion (sagittal) and contralateral rotation (transverse) driven by the obliques and rectus abdominis. Hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) produce the leg drive; knees flex/extend in a cycling pattern. Shoulders/arms assist in driving the rotational reach and the cervical muscles stabilize the head. Core stabilizers (transverse abdominis, multifidus) and pelvic control are required to prevent excessive lumbar extension or anterior pelvic tilt.
notes: Classification assumes the supine bicycle-crunch style 'air bike' (bodyweight core exercise). If the user meant the fan/assault stationary 'air bike' (arms/legs cycling for conditioning), primary patterns would be cyclical LOCOMOTION/UPPER-LIMB DRIVE rather than ROTATION.

reasoning: The AirDyne is a cyclic, reciprocal whole-body pedaling/cranking task. Primary joint actions occur at the hip, knee and ankle as repeated sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion→extension and ankle dorsiflexion→plantarflexion producing leg-driven propulsion (locomotion pattern). Simultaneously the upper limbs perform alternating sagittal-plane shoulder/elbow push and pull actions on the handles (horizontal/linear push-pull actions). Core and spinal extensors/abdominals act isometrically to maintain posture and transfer force between upper and lower body; scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff control shoulder motion. Movement is symmetric and rhythmic so anti-rotation is minimal.
notes: Variations: seated vs. standing on pedals changes trunk demand; higher arm emphasis if user aggressively cranks handles increases relative contribution of PUSH/PULL. Symmetrical bilateral action means little anti-rotation unless performed single-arm or asymmetrically.

reasoning: This is a mobility/stretching exercise rather than a locomotor or load-handling pattern. The primary joint actions are hip extension (thigh moves posteriorly relative to pelvis) and knee flexion (heel drawn toward glute). These are performed largely as a passive/assisted stretch while the upper limbs bear weight in a quadruped position to stabilize the torso. Primary movement occurs in the sagittal plane. Shoulders and elbows act isometrically to support bodyweight and stabilize the scapulothoracic and glenohumeral joints; the trunk (spine) maintains a neutral to slightly extended posture and provides core stabilization.
primary_muscles: gluteus maximus (hip extensor producing hip extension)
hamstrings (assist hip extension and knee flexion)
quadriceps - rectus femoris (primary muscle being stretched)
notes: This is primarily a static assisted stretch for the quadriceps/rectus femoris performed from a quadruped position; it does not map cleanly to common training movement patterns (squat, hinge, lunge, push, pull, carry, rotation, anti-rotation, locomotion). Variations include unilateral hold, adding anterior pelvic tilt to increase rectus femoris stretch, or performing a prone quad stretch which changes trunk/shoulder stabilization demands. Protect the knee by using padding and avoid forcing hip extension if there is anterior hip pain.

reasoning: Primary movement is trunk lateral flexion (side crunch) with a small component of sagittal trunk flexion as the upper torso lifts toward the pelvis. The spine (lumbar) is the primary moving joint performing frontal-plane lateral flexion and sagittal-plane flexion. The oblique muscles produce the side‑to‑side reaching action while the rectus abdominis contributes to the flexion component. The pelvis and hips remain relatively fixed, requiring isometric stabilization from the transverse abdominis, pelvic stabilizers and hip extensors; scapular/shoulder muscles guide the hand but are not primary movers.
notes: Often called heel taps/side crunches; primarily a unilateral trunk lateral-flexion/core pattern. Variation: performing with feet elevated or adding rotation to reach opposite heel increases transverse-plane demand (more true rotation). If excessive hip/leg movement occurs, hip flexor involvement increases.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion (single-arm curls) produced in the sagittal plane with accompanying forearm supination (transverse). The incline bench places the shoulder in a slightly more extended starting position, lengthening the long head of the biceps, so the shoulder acts primarily as a stabilizer with minor sagittal excursion. Because the exercise is performed unilaterally/alternately, the trunk and anti-rotational core musculature must resist rotational/lateral torque produced by the off-center load. Primary movers are elbow flexors/supinators (biceps, brachialis, brachioradialis/supinator); secondary stabilizers include rotator cuff, scapular stabilizers and ipsilateral obliques for anti-rotation while the bench supports the spine.

joint_actions.action: stabilization with slight extension at start (minimal sagittal excursion)

notes: Bench support reduces need for global trunk stabilization compared with standing curls. Incline position increases long-head biceps stretch; supinated grip emphasizes biceps brachii. If performed strictly bilateral/symmetric, ANTI_ROTATION could be omitted; palms-neutral or hammer variations change emphasis to brachioradialis.

reasoning: Primary action is dynamic single-leg propulsion and landing in a diagonal direction (plyometric locomotion). Takeoff involves triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) producing horizontal/diagonal translation of the center of mass; landing requires eccentric control of the same joints. Because the movement is unilateral and diagonal it imposes transverse/frontal plane rotational and lateral moments on the trunk and pelvis that the core and hip stabilizers resist isometrically, so anti-rotation stabilization is a meaningful secondary pattern. Primary movers produce hip extension (glute max, hamstrings), knee extension (quadriceps) and ankle plantarflexion (calves) for the bound, while hip abductors/adductors and obliques control frontal/transverse plane alignment on landing.
notes: Diagonal/unilateral plyometric — emphasize single-leg strength, frontal plane hip control (prevent valgus), and progressive loading. Surface, distance and single-leg landing mechanics alter demands; can be biased more frontal or sagittal depending on direction of bound.

reasoning: Primary movement is repeated elbow flexion in the sagittal plane with a neutral (hammer) grip. Elbow flexion is the primary joint action, produced mainly by brachialis, brachioradialis and biceps brachii (hammer grip emphasizes brachioradialis/brachialis). The shoulder remains relatively static (isometric) with scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff maintaining humeral position. Because the load is unilateral/alternating, the trunk and contralateral obliques/erector spinae act isometrically to resist transverse-plane rotation (anti-rotation). Wrist/forearm muscles stabilize the neutral grip.
notes: If performed bilaterally or with a bar, anti-rotation demand decreases. Seated or braced variations reduce core anti-rotation requirements. Hammer grip emphasizes brachioradialis relative to supinated curl.

reasoning: Primary joint action is shoulder abduction (glenohumeral joint) in the frontal plane performed alternately by each arm. The middle deltoid (with supraspinatus initiation) produces the concentric abduction. The scapulothoracic joint performs coupled upward rotation (trapezius and serratus anterior) to allow full elevation. When performed unilaterally/alternating, the asymmetric arm position imposes an anti-rotational/isometric demand on the trunk to resist torso rotation and lateral flexion. Elbow and wrist are largely stabilizing. Therefore the movement maps to an upper-body PUSH-style shoulder elevation pattern with secondary ANTI_ROTATION stabilization demands for unilateral/asymmetric loading.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (slight flexion or extended depending on form)

notes: If the raise is performed bilaterally simultaneously and loaded symmetrically, anti-rotation demand is reduced. reasoning: Primary movement is a unilateral horizontal push from a supine/floor position: shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) combined with elbow extension (sagittal plane) to press the load. The prime movers are pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps producing the concentric press. Because the press is performed one arm at a time (asymmetric loading), the trunk/oblique system and contralateral shoulder girdle act isometrically to resist rotation and maintain torso alignment, so anti-rotation stabilization is a required secondary pattern. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower traps, rotator cuff) also control scapulothoracic position against the floor during the press. Range of motion at the shoulder is often limited by the floor, reducing scapular upward rotation and emphasizing triceps lockout and pec activation during the final portion of the press.
notes: Floor press typically limits shoulder range (elbows contact floor) which reduces shoulder extension/vertical pressing demand. Alternating (single-arm) versions increase core anti-rotation demand; using a neutral-grip or different implements (dumbbell, kettlebell, band) can alter scapular and rotator cuff loading.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: unilateral/alternating overhead press produced by concentric shoulder elevation (overhead flexion) and elbow extension in the sagittal plane. Because the load is applied unilaterally and alternates, the torso and core must resist rotational and lateral displacement, producing an anti-rotation/isometric stabilization demand in the transverse plane. Scapular upward rotation and stabilization occur to allow full overhead motion. Primary movers: deltoids and triceps create the press; upper traps/serratus assist scapular motion; obliques and transverse abdominis produce/isometrically resist rotation.
notes: Cable line and hand position can shift the emphasis slightly toward frontal plane abduction or transverse-plane stabilization; strictly bilateral simultaneous presses reduce anti-rotation demand. Ensure scapular upward rotation and rotator cuff control for shoulder health.

exercise: Alternating KB 'boat' leg lifts (pass KB under legs)
reasoning: Primary movement is alternating hip flexion/extension of the legs in a seated/V‑sit (boat) position — hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) drive the leg movement while the trunk is held in a fixed flexed position (isometric spinal flexion) to maintain the boat. Passing a kettlebell under/between the legs produces transverse‑plane hand/torso translation and asymmetric loading that imposes both dynamic rotation (to move the load across midline) and isometric anti‑rotation demand (obliques/transverse abdominis resist unwanted spinal rotation). Shoulders and scapular stabilizers also act to control and guide the kettlebell during the pass. Primary movers are the hip flexors and dynamic leg musculature; the core (rectus abdominis, obliques, transverse abdominis) functions primarily as an isometric stabilizer (anti‑extension and anti‑rotation).

joint_actions.action: resist and produce rotation (dynamic pass + anti‑rotation)
near‑isometric extension (if legs straight) / slight flexion control

notes: Varied hand/arm patterns (single‑arm pass vs two‑hand pass) change anti‑rotation demand. Bending knees reduces hip flexor load and increases spinal flexion relative contribution. Avoid excessive lumbar rounding in individuals with low spinal flexion tolerance.

reasoning: Primary movement occurs at the ankle complex (talocrural and subtalar joints) producing circumduction/rotation that combines dorsiflexion/plantarflexion (sagittal), inversion/eversion (frontal) and transverse components. The action is primarily a multi-planar rotational mobilization of the foot/ankle rather than a load-bearing transfer pattern. Hip and knee remain isometrically stable to provide a fixed lever for the distal rotation; minimal spinal involvement. Stabilization is primarily distal (intrinsic foot muscles) and proximal isometric stabilization of the tibia, knee and hip to isolate ankle motion.
notes: Primarily a mobility/stretching/mobilization exercise. Can be performed seated, supine, or standing; standing variations require greater proximal stabilization and balance. Useful as an ankle mobility warm-up or rehab drill. If the focus is spinal/trunk rotation (rare), include ROTATION for torso; otherwise this is localized ankle rotation.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are vertical shoulder press movements (glenohumeral elevation/shoulder flexion with scapular upward rotation) and elbow extension in the sagittal plane producing the lift (PUSH). Because the load is unilateral and alternating, the torso and core must produce isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion forces to resist spinal rotation and lateral tilt (ANTI_ROTATION). Secondary stabilization occurs through the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers and the lower-limb/postural musculature to maintain upright stance.

joint_actions.action: upward rotation and protraction (scapular movement to allow overhead reach)
isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion (resists transverse rotation and frontal plane tilt)
isometric stabilization to maintain upright stance

notes: If performed with leg drive (push-press) the pattern includes lower-body drive components; seated variations reduce anti-rotation demand. Load position (racked vs. bottom-up) can change scapular and forearm stabilization requirements. Alternating unilateral pressing increases lateral core demand compared with bilateral overhead press.

reasoning: This is a figure‑4/ankle‑on‑knee stretch that places the femur into external rotation of the hip (primary action) with associated hip abduction and some hip flexion depending on position. The crossed limb's knee is flexed. The position lengthens and unloads the deep external rotators (piriformis, obturators, gemelli, quadratus femoris) and involves the gluteals. Stabilization requires isometric activity from the contralateral hip and pelvic stabilizers and trunk/core to maintain posture; the supporting limb provides weight‑bearing stability.
notes: Commonly performed seated or supine (reclined pigeon). Primarily a mobility/stretch exercise; if performed dynamically or with external resistance it could involve additional patterns (e.g., ANTI_ROTATION if asymmetric load added).

reasoning: This is a self‑myofascial release (soft‑tissue mobilization) aimed at the tibialis anterior. It does not produce a primary functional movement pattern (no loaded multi‑joint movement). The only joint action typically involved is small, often passive or assisted, ankle dorsiflexion and slight inversion/eversion while applying compressive pressure along the muscle belly. Stabilization demands are minimal and local (foot/ankle position and balance) rather than gross anti‑rotation/carry/push/pull patterns.
notes: Classified as non‑patterned mobility/soft‑tissue work rather than a movement pattern. Variations include foam‑roller vs. lacrosse ball application and adding active dorsiflexion to increase neural/muscle mobilization. Exercise contraindications: acute tibial/ankle fractures, open wounds, deep vein thrombosis, endocrine-related neuropathy without medical clearance. If active ankle motion is emphasized and integrated into gait or loaded tasks, reclassify under LOCOMOTION or CARRY as appropriate.

reasoning: The hang clean is initiated from a hinged position with powerful hip/knee/ankle extension (triple extension) to generate vertical velocity — this is a HINGE-dominant action. Immediately following triple extension the shoulder girdle/scapula and elbow produce a high vertical pull to elevate the load (PULL). When performed alternating single-arm (as implied by 'alternating'), the unilateral load creates a rotational moment about the spine that must be resisted isometrically, so anti-rotational core stabilization is required (ANTI_ROTATION). Primary movers for force production are the posterior chain (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) and quads for extension, calves for plantarflexion, and upper trapezius/shoulder complex and elbow flexors for the vertical pull; the core/obliques and contralateral trunk muscles act isometrically to prevent rotation. Stabilization demands include spinal extension control, scapular stability (rotator cuff/traps/lats), and single-leg/postural control during the catch/transfer phase.

joint_actions.action: flexion (during pull) then rapid re-orientation/partial extension to rack

notes: If performed bilateral with a barbell the ANTI_ROTATION demand is reduced; if the catch is dropped into a full squat the movement includes a greater SQUAT component but primary mechanics remain HINGE + PULL. Equipment (dumbbell/kettlebell/barbell) and single-arm vs double-arm change stabilization demands but not the primary pattern classification.

reasoning: The term 'Anti-Gravity Press' most commonly denotes a pressing action performed against gravity (i.e., a vertical or horizontal press). The PRIMARY joint actions are shoulder elevation (producing upward/forward displacement of the hand) and elbow extension. Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff act to control glenohumeral position; the trunk and hips provide isometric stabilization against extension/rotation depending on body position. Without an explicit description/video, the dominant mechanical pattern is a PUSH (vertical if overhead-style, horizontal if performed supine/lying). If the exercise is single-arm or asymmetric, anti-rotation demands would be added, and if performed while moving the body through space different pattern additions could apply.
notes: Description inferred from name only. Current classification flags for manual review due to ambiguous naming.

reasoning: Primary motion is shoulder circumduction — a compound rotational movement combining shoulder flexion/extension, abduction/adduction and internal/external rotation across the sagittal, frontal and transverse planes. The rotator cuff muscles and deltoids create movement while the scapular stabilizers (trapezius, serratus anterior) control glenohumeral/scapulothoracic position. Elbows remain near-isometric with minimal motion; the spine and core act isometrically to maintain posture and resist unwanted torso movement.

joint_actions.action: circumduction (combination of flexion/extension, abduction/adduction, internal/external rotation)

notes: Variation by direction (forward/backward), circle size, and speed; small/slow circles emphasize rotator cuff and scapular control, large/fast circles add dynamic shoulder mobility. If performed with load or unilateral asymmetry, consider adding CARRY or ANTI_ROTATION as appropriate.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical push: concentric shoulder elevation (combined shoulder flexion/abduction) and elbow extension to press the load overhead. The exercise also includes deliberate transverse-plane humeral rotation (internal-to-external rotation of the shoulder) during the press (the signature 'Arnold' rotation). Scapular upward rotation occurs to allow full overhead range. Core and thoracic/posterior chain act isometrically to stabilize the trunk, especially when performed standing.

joint_actions.action: external rotation (progression from internal to external through the movement)

notes: Seated versions reduce core and lower-body stabilization demands. Single-arm or alternating variations increase anti-rotation and lateral stabilization demand. Pay attention to shoulder rotation mechanics; some individuals may experience impingement with extreme ranges—modify ROM or grip as needed.

reasoning: The Arched Hang is performed hanging from an overhead bar while actively creating thoracic/lumbar extension (an 'arched' body). Primary joint actions are shoulder girdle/shoulder position at or near end-range overhead (functional shoulder flexion with scapular retraction/depression occurring isometrically) and spinal extension (thoracic/lumbar). Hips are held in slight extension to maintain the arch and elbows remain extended (isometric). The movement is therefore best classified as a vertical PULL pattern because the body is suspended from an overhead grip and requires vertical pulling/ hanging mechanics with strong scapular control. Stabilization demands include active scapular retraction/depression (lower trapezius, rhomboids), rotator cuff control at the glenohumeral joint, and posterior chain/erector spinae and gluteal activation to maintain the arch rather than collapse into spinal flexion.
notes: Mobility/warm-up exercise emphasizing thoracic extension and scapular control. Progressions/variants: passive hang, hollow hang, arch-to-hang alternations. Caution with shoulder impingement or poor scapular/rotator cuff control; cue active scapular depression/retraction and posterior chain engagement.

reasoning: Arm swings are a dynamic shoulder mobility pattern emphasizing transverse- and sagittal-plane humeral motion. The primary joint action occurs at the glenohumeral joint (repeated flexion/extension and horizontal adduction/abduction) with coordinated scapulothoracic protraction/retraction and rotator-cuff–mediated control. Elbows are typically extended and act as levers (isometric/stable). The trunk and scapular stabilizers provide isometric control to allow smooth pendular/rotational shoulder motion. Because the movement is predominately transverse (cross-body/horizontal) and involves rotational components of the upper limb and scapula, it best matches the ROTATION pattern for warm-up/mobility work.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
notes: Variations include sagittal-plane forward/backward swings, transverse cross-body swings, and arm circles. Emphasize scapular control and rotator-cuff engagement; caution with aggressive ranges in individuals with shoulder pathology.

reasoning: Primary movement is open‑chain shoulder flexion/extension (dynamic swing forward and backward) with occasional horizontal adduction/abduction if swings cross the midline. The exercise is a mobility/warmup pattern that emphasizes repeated sagittal-plane shoulder excursions similar to an unloaded, unresisted pushing action of the arm rather than a loaded pull. Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles act isometrically or eccentrically to control the humeral head; the core and thorax provide proximal stability to limit excessive trunk motion.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: minimal stabilization / slight rotation or extension if trunk moves

notes: Common variations include front-to-back (sagittal) swings, cross‑body swings (transverse), and alternating reciprocal arm swings. Keep elbows soft and maintain scapular control; not a loaded push pattern but best categorized with PUSH due to primary shoulder flexion/extension mechanics. If the drill emphasizes torso rotation or resisted band swings, consider adding ROTATION or ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: Lifting an atlas stone from the ground to the lap/shoulder is initiated primarily as a hip-dominant hinge (powerful hip extension) similar to a deadlift, with substantial knee extension as the lifter often partially squats to position the hips under the stone. The movement requires pulling the load off the ground using posterior chain and lat/arm engagement (PULL) and then a squat-like drive/stand to fully lift the stone to the lap or platform (SQUAT component). The trunk remains in strong anti-flexion (isometric spinal extension) while the upper limbs flex/adduct to secure and manipulate the stone. Stabilization demands include heavy core anti-flexion, scapular/shoulder stabilization, and strong grip/forearm isometrics.
notes: Variation depends on technique and stone progression: lighter/single-stone work may emphasize a more pronounced squat transfer (greater SQUAT), while heavy ground-to-platform lifts emphasize HINGE+PULL. Asymmetric handling or walking with the stone would add ANTI_ROTATION or CARRY respectively.

reasoning: Around The Worlds is primarily a multi-planar circumduction of the glenohumeral joint: the arm moves through shoulder flexion → abduction → extension → adduction and includes humeral internal/external rotation. Primary joint action is shoulder circumduction (multi-planar) with coordinated scapulothoracic upward rotation and protraction/retraction to preserve ROM. Rotator cuff muscles control humeral head centration and rotational components while deltoids, pecs and lats drive the gross arc; trapezius and serratus anterior produce scapular motion. Elbow is typically held extended isometrically and the spine/core provide postural stabilization.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: circumduction (combination of flexion, abduction, extension, adduction)

notes: Often performed as a mobility/activation drill; when loaded (dumbbells) it increases demand on deltoids and scapular stabilizers. If performed with pronounced trunk rotation or heavy unilateral load, consider adding ROTATION/ANTI_ROTATION or unilateral PUSH/PULL as appropriate.

reasoning: Primary joint action is shoulder horizontal abduction (transverse plane) produced by posterior deltoid with concomitant scapular retraction/adduction (scapulothoracic joint) driven by middle trapezius and rhomboids. Elbows remain slightly flexed/near rigid and play a minor role. When performed bent-over the thoracic spine must isometrically resist flexion and rotation to maintain posture. The dominant mechanic is a horizontal pulling motion of the shoulder girdle (a horizontal pull/isolation of posterior shoulder and scapular retractors).
notes: Variations: standing band pull-apart emphasizes scapular retraction (more upright); bent-over reverse fly increases thoracic stabilization demand. Single-arm or one-sided loading introduces greater anti-rotation demand and may warrant inclusion of ANTI_ROTATION in classification.

reasoning: Primary joint action is spinal extension (thoracic and lumbar) in the sagittal plane as the thoracic spine is taken into extension over the arch. Shoulders often go into passive extension/abduction and scapular retraction as the chest opens. Hips and knees remain largely stationary (neutral or slight extension) and act as stabilizers. Because the available movement pattern set lacks a dedicated 'spinal extension / mobility' category, PULL is the closest match: the posterior chain and scapular retractors are being lengthened/loaded in extension similar to a posterior pull orientation. Stabilization requires pelvic control, relaxed hip extensors, and diaphragmatic breathing to allow controlled spinal extension.
notes: Mobility/cooldown exercise emphasizing spinal extension; beware of pre-existing lumbar pathology or acute pain — perform gently and progress range. If classification scheme allowed, a dedicated 'SPINAL EXTENSION / MOBILITY' pattern would be more precise.

reasoning: Atlas stone lifting is a compound lift that is initiated primarily by hip-dominant extension (hinge) to break the stone from the ground and engage the posterior chain, then transitions into a more knee-dominant squat pattern as the athlete pulls the stone onto the lap and rises to stand. Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane; the shoulders and elbows perform flexion/adduction to cradle and maneuver the stone to the chest and onto a platform, while the spine functions isometrically/through controlled extension to stabilize the load. Grip and upper-back muscles assist in holding and controlling the stone but are secondary to the hip/knee-driven lift.

joint_actions.action: flexion and horizontal adduction (cradling/rolling the stone)
isometric extension / controlled flexion when wrapping

notes: Variations include lap-and-load (common), loading to different platform heights, or shouldering stones — these can add greater shoulder/press components or asymmetry. Though upper-body pulling/gripping is important, primary demand is posterior chain (hinge) with a squat-like receive and stand. Watch lumbar shear and grip fatigue; asymmetric or single-arm variations introduce anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are transverse-plane trunk rotation (torque generation from pelvis/thorax), transverse-plane shoulder horizontal adduction (punching motion), and sagittal-plane elbow extension. Lower-limb joints perform repeated sagittal-plane stepping (hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension) and transverse-plane hip rotation for weight transfer/rotation. Thus the movement is primarily a horizontal PUSH (arm/shoulder extension and horizontal adduction), coupled with dynamic ROTATION of the spine and hips to generate power, and LOCOMOTION via quick stepping/weight-shift footwork. Stabilization demands include scapular stability (serratus anterior, rotator cuff) to control shoulder position, and anti-rotation/isometric core control from obliques and deep trunk stabilizers between rotational phases.

joint_actions.action: protraction/retraction and upward rotation for punch reach

notes: Variations (power punches with heavier rotation or planted stance) increase emphasis on ROTATION and hip drive; shadowboxing without foot movement reduces LOCOMOTION and increases in-place anti-rotation/isometric demands. If punches are performed isometrically or as static striking, classify more as ROTATION+PUSH (reduced LOCOMOTION).

reasoning: This exercise is a sequence of straight punches (jab and cross) delivered with trunk and hip rotation transferring force into a unilateral horizontal pushing action of the arm. Primary joint actions are transverse-plane rotation at the spine and hips (generating torque) with concomitant shoulder horizontal flexion/protraction and elbow extension to deliver the punch. The core (obliques, transverse abdominis) and hip musculature produce and transmit rotational force; the anterior deltoid, pectoralis major and triceps execute the horizontal push. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower/mid traps) and lower-limb stabilizers produce isometric and dynamic stabilization for force transfer and balance.
notes: If performed with stepping or weight transfer, lower-limb sagittal actions (hip/knee flexion-extension, ankle plantar/dorsiflexion) contribute to LOCOMOTION elements, but the core rotation and horizontal push remain primary. Asymmetric single-arm striking does not require anti-rotation classification because the trunk actively rotates rather than purely resisting rotation.

reasoning: Primary actions are repeated upper‑body pushes (horizontal pushing/protraction and elbow extension) combined with transverse plane axial rotation of the trunk and hips to generate force and weight transfer. Shoulders and elbows produce the punching motion (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, triceps, serratus anterior), while the spine and hips rotate (internal/external obliques, gluteal complex, hip rotators) to add power and reach. Secondary requirements include scapular and rotator cuff stabilization, lower‑limb force transfer through hip extension/plantarflexion and single‑leg stance stability. Because the action explicitly includes transverse plane rotation for force production, ROTATION is included along with the primary horizontal PUSH.

joint_actions.action: rotation with weight transfer (and partial extension)

notes: Variation by strike: jab predominantly horizontal push with less rotation; cross/hook emphasize greater trunk/hip rotation. Footwork/locomotion around the bag can add LOCOMOTION when included. reasoning: Bag kicks (especially roundhouse-style or turning kicks) are primarily single-leg, ballistic hip-driven strikes with dominant transverse-plane hip rotation of the kicking limb and knee extension to transfer force into the bag. The hip performs rotational (and often abduction/adduction) actions to generate the kick while the trunk and stance limb produce isometric anti-rotational forces to stabilize the torso and transfer force. Primary movers (hip rotators, gluteals, quadriceps) produce the dynamic rotation and limb extension; the core (obliques, erector spinae) and stance-leg hip abductors/adductors/isometrically stabilize against rotation and lateral collapse.
primary_muscles: gluteus medius/minimus (stance and kicking limb stabilization)
hip external/internal rotators (e.g., piriformis, obturators, gemelli)
notes: Pattern assumes roundhouse/rotational-style bag kicks. If the exercise strictly uses front/push kicks (sagittal hip extension with minimal rotation) the primary pattern would be sagittal hip/knee extension and confidence in ROTATION would decrease; include LOCOMOTION only if performed as travelling/marching kicks. Single-leg balance and reactive impact variability increase core/hip stabilizer demands.

reasoning: The backward drag is performed by walking backward while pulling a load behind you (sled/rope/harness). The primary movement is locomotion—repeated hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane driving backward gait. Simultaneously the upper body produces a horizontal/ posterior-directed pull on the load (shoulder extension/scapular retraction and elbow flexion) to overcome external resistance. Primary movers for gait (glutes, hamstrings, quads, calves) produce the stepping motion while lats, rhomboids/traps and biceps generate the pulling force; the erector spinae and abdominal/core muscles act isometrically to stabilize the spine and transfer force between lower and upper body.

notes: If performed purely as a stationary pull (no stepping) classification would shift toward PULL only. Asymmetric load or unilateral grip introduces ANTI_ROTATION demands.
