reasoning: Primary joint actions are bilateral hip flexion and knee flexion in the sagittal plane with accompanying lumbar/spinal flexion and posterior pelvic tilt. The movement is an open-chain, non–weight-bearing hip/knee flexion pattern that mechanically corresponds to the same sagittal plane hip+knee flexion/extension pattern used in closed-chain squatting (hip and knee angle change as the knees move toward the torso). Muscles producing the motion include the hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris), knee flexors (hamstrings) assisting knee flexion depending on technique, and spinal flexors/abdominals (rectus abdominis) driving/orienting the trunk and posterior pelvic tilt. Stabilization requirements are minimal load-bearing but include isometric control of the scapulothoracic region if holding a bag, and low-level engagement of the deep core and hip stabilizers to control pelvic position and prevent unwanted rotation.
notes: This is primarily a mobility/recovery drill (open-chain hip+knee flexion) and not a loaded squatting exercise; SQUAT is chosen because the defining joint actions (hip and knee flexion in the sagittal plane) match the squat movement pattern conceptually. Variations: unilateral single-leg draw-in emphasizes hip flexors and core asymmetry; using the bag to assist changes load/stability but does not change primary joint actions.

reasoning: Primary movement is knee flexion/extension in the sagittal plane as the heels draw the ball toward the hips (concentric knee flexion, eccentric knee extension). The hips are held in near-full extension and act isometrically to maintain a posteriorly tilted pelvis and elevated torso (hip extension stabilization). Hamstrings generate the primary concentric force to pull the ball; gluteus maximus and erector spinae maintain hip extension isometrically and the core and hip abductors stabilize the pelvis and prevent transverse/frontal plane motion. The exercise therefore is primarily a knee-dominant pull (hamstring curl) with a significant hinge-style hip extension stabilization demand.
notes: Often performed supine with heels on a stability ball or sliders. Primary training effect is hamstring knee-flexion (closed-chain with ball), while isometric hip extension increases posterior chain and core stabilization demand. Single-leg variations increase unilateral hip and core stabilization (anti-rotation components).

reasoning: Primary joint actions are shoulder extension and adduction and elbow flexion in the sagittal (and frontal for adduction) plane as the body is elevated toward the bar. Scapulothoracic retraction and depression occur as prime scapular motions to initiate and finish the pull. The band provides assistance but does not change the fundamental vertical pulling pattern. Primary movers (latissimus dorsi, teres major, biceps) produce shoulder extension/adduction and elbow flexion; scapular retractors (rhomboids, middle/lower traps) control scapular motion. The core and lower body act isometrically to stabilize the spine and pelvis during the vertical pull.
notes: Band assistance reduces required concentric force but maintains the vertical pulling pattern. Grip variation (supinated/pronated/neutral) shifts emphasis toward biceps or lats. Emphasize scapular pull/retraction before elbow flexion for technical proficiency.

reasoning: Primary joint actions occur at the shoulder (glenohumeral horizontal abduction) combined with scapulothoracic retraction in the transverse plane. The movement is a horizontal pulling action emphasizing scapular adduction (retraction) and posterior shoulder musculature. Elbows are typically held near full extension (isometric) while the spine and core maintain a neutral, isometric posture for stabilization. Primary movers produce shoulder horizontal abduction and scapular retraction while rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint and spinal/core muscles provide postural stability.
notes: Variations include single-arm band pull-aparts, higher or lower arm positions (changes moment arm) and face-pull variants that add external rotation; maintain scapular retraction and avoid upper-trap elevation to target mid/lower scapular musculature.

reasoning: Band dislocates are a shoulder mobility/movement drill that primarily takes the glenohumeral joint through large ranges of flexion to extension (passing the arms overhead and behind), with concurrent scapulothoracic motion (upward rotation, posterior tilt and retraction) and thoracic extension. The primary joint action is glenohumeral flexion (raising the arms) and controlled glenohumeral extension/horizontal abduction as the arms pass behind the body in the sagittal/frontal transitional plane. Scapular retractors and upward rotators (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids, serratus anterior) control the scapula, while posterior shoulder and rotator cuff musculature eccentrically lengthen and concentrically control the return. Elbows remain mostly extended and act isometrically to transmit the band force. Core and thoracic extensors facilitate thoracic extension and stability. Because the exercise is a mobility/pass-through emphasizing shoulder extension/retraction under band tension, it maps best to a PULL-type movement pattern (scapular retraction/shoulder extension mechanics).

joint_actions.action: flexion → extension/horizontal abduction (pass-through overhead to behind)

notes: Primarily a shoulder mobility/drill rather than a strength movement—classification as PULL reflects the dominant scapular retraction/shoulder extension mechanics under band tension. Variations (narrower grip, PVC, or using a stiffer band) change loading and emphasize rotator cuff or scapular control differently. If performed explosively with active pulling to the chest, classification confidence could shift toward a more explicit PULL/ROW pattern.

reasoning: Standing on an unstable surface requires continuous isometric stabilization of the core to resist rotational and lateral perturbations, and rapid small adjustments at the ankle, knee and hip to maintain upright posture. Primary joint actions are small sagittal-plane dorsiflexion/plantarflexion and frontal-plane inversion/eversion at the ankle, with isometric/near-isometric control of knee and hip flexion/extension and frontal-plane hip ab/adduction to keep the center of mass over the base of support. The spine and oblique system act isometrically to resist rotation and to maintain trunk alignment while lower-limb muscles perform fine motor corrections.
notes: This classification assumes a static or quasi-static balance stance. If the balance board is used for dynamic tasks (squats, lunges, single-leg hops, rotational throws), add corresponding patterns (SQUAT, LUNGE, LOCOMOTION, ROTATION) and increase emphasis on prime movers for those actions.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane against band resistance (a pulling pattern at the elbow). The pronated grip (reverse curl) shifts emphasis away from the biceps toward brachioradialis and brachialis; wrist extensors often act to maintain wrist position. Shoulder and scapular musculature act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm and girdle; the core provides postural stabilization. The band provides variable resistance requiring concentric and eccentric control of elbow flexion/extension.
primary_muscles: wrist extensors (e.g., extensor carpi radialis longus/brevis)
notes: Pronated (reverse) grip emphasizes brachioradialis/brachialis — useful for elbow/forearm rehabilitation. Single-arm or offset loading introduces additional anti-rotation demand. Use light band tension and pain-free range for rehab; wrist position influences forearm muscle recruitment.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal/face-level pull with scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction) and glenohumeral external rotation in the transverse/horizontal plane. Elbow flexion is used to bring the hands toward the face. The exercise primarily uses posterior shoulder and scapular stabilizers to pull and externally rotate the humerus; the trunk and core act isometrically to maintain posture and prevent torso movement.
notes: Light band emphasizes scapular control and rotator-cuff external rotation; perform with controlled external rotation and scapular retraction to avoid excessive upper-trap elevation. Variation: high-elbow face-pull emphasizes posterior deltoid and mid/lower trap, lower-elbow variation shifts emphasis slightly to rhomboids and lats.

reasoning: Band scapular work primarily produces scapulothoracic retraction (and often controlled retraction-to-protraction sequences) with the clavicular/scapular girdle moving in the transverse plane. The primary joint action is scapular retraction (adduction) which is a horizontal pulling action of the shoulder girdle; the glenohumeral joint may have slight horizontal abduction but is usually a secondary mover. Elbow typically remains extended and the thorax/spine stabilizes isometrically to provide a stable base. Muscles producing the movement include the middle trapezius and rhomboids for retraction, posterior deltoid and teres minor/infraspinatus contributing when there is GH horizontal abduction/external rotation, and the lower trapezius/serratus anterior coordinating scapular control. Scapular stabilizers and core act isometrically to maintain posture during the band work.

joint_actions.action: scapular protraction (abduction) - often part of full sequence

notes: Classification assumes common band pull-apart/scapular retraction warm-up. If the drill emphasizes protraction (e.g., push-up plus) or banded overhead serratus work, include PUSH or emphasize serratus anterior. If bands are used for isolated external rotation, rotator cuff focus is increased but overall pattern remains scapular control (PULL dominant).

reasoning: Primary joint action is glenohumeral internal/external rotation in the transverse plane (often with the elbow held at ~90°). The rotator cuff muscles (infraspinatus, teres minor for external rotation; subscapularis for internal rotation) produce the rotation while the deltoids assist and scapular stabilizers (trapezius, serratus anterior) maintain scapulothoracic position. The elbow is typically held isometrically (flexed) to position the forearm; the thorax/spine remains isometrically stabilized to prevent compensatory axial rotation or shoulder elevation. As a warm-up/mobility drill the movement is primarily rotational rather than a push/pull pattern.
notes: Common variations: performed with elbow at side or abducted ~90°. Band anchor position changes line of pull and relative emphasis on scapular vs glenohumeral rotation. Cue scapular stability and avoid excessive shoulder elevation or trunk rotation; regress to lighter band or perform unweighted rotations if pain is present.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow extension against band resistance in the sagittal plane (single-joint upper-body pushing action). The triceps produce concentric elbow extension; the shoulder complex and scapular muscles act isometrically to position and stabilize the upper arm and torso. If performed unilaterally or with an off-center anchor there is increased anti-rotation demand, but the primary pattern remains a PUSH.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (may have slight flexion/extension depending on band anchor/arm angle)

notes: If performed standing with a single-arm band anchor, add anti-rotation stabilization demand. Anchor position (overhead vs. behind head) changes shoulder moment arm and degree of shoulder involvement but does not change primary classification as PUSH (elbow extension).

reasoning: Primary movement is hip adduction at the hip joint in the frontal plane — the working leg moves toward the midline against band resistance. The exercise trains the adductor complex concentrically (adduction) and eccentrically on return. During a standing variation the contralateral supporting limb must isometrically stabilize the pelvis and maintain a single-leg stance, engaging hip abductors and core to prevent pelvic drop/rotation. Knee and ankle remain largely isometric/stabilizing rather than producing primary movement.
notes: Commonly performed standing (unilateral) or seated. Standing variation requires stronger single-leg stabilization (gluteus medius/minimus) and balance. Band placement (ankle vs. knee) alters moment arm and challenge. Although hip adduction is a component of gait/locomotion, this is an isolation/frontal-plane exercise rather than a true locomotor task; classification as LOCOMOTION is an inferred mapping to the available pattern set and may be flagged for review.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are scapulothoracic retraction (scapular adduction) and shoulder horizontal abduction with shoulder external rotation as the band is pulled toward the face; the elbows flex to assist the pull. These actions occur mainly in the transverse plane (shoulder/scapula) with elbow flexion in the sagittal plane. The movement is a horizontal pull pattern emphasizing scapular retractors and posterior shoulder external rotators; the trunk and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to maintain posture and scapular positioning.
notes: Typically performed bilaterally as a horizontal pull/rotator-cuff strengthening exercise. Single-arm or asymmetric variations introduce anti-rotation/core demand (would add ANTI_ROTATION). Cue scapular retraction and external rotation; avoid excessive neck extension or upper trapezius over-activation.

reasoning: Primary joint actions occur at the shoulder complex and elbow. The exercise is a horizontal/diagonal pulling pattern performed in the transverse plane that emphasizes scapular retraction (adduction) and glenohumeral external rotation while the elbows flex to pull the band toward the face. The primary movers are posterior shoulder and scapular retractors (posterior deltoid, middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids) and the external rotators of the rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor). The trunk/spine acts isometrically to maintain an upright posture and prevent excessive thoracic flexion; the core and scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior to an extent) provide stabilization. Because the dominant mechanical action is a pulling motion of the shoulder/elbow (scapular retraction + external rotation), the movement classifies as PULL.

joint_actions.action: scapular retraction (horizontal pull) + glenohumeral external rotation

notes: Typically a shoulder-health/rotator-cuff–focused pull variation emphasizing external rotation and scapular control. Use light resistance and focus on scapular retraction and external rotation; perform with thumbs-up/rope to bias external rotators. Avoid excessive thoracic rounding or shrugging.

reasoning: Primary movement is multi-planar glenohumeral motion (shoulder flexion/abduction with horizontal translation) combined with active scapulothoracic motion (protraction/retraction and upward rotation). The drill emphasizes scapular control and rotator-cuff-mediated humeral rotation as the arms travel overhead and behind; therefore primary pattern aligns with a scapular-driven 'pull' (scapular retraction/upward rotation) rather than a loaded push or lower-body pattern. Stabilization demands include isometric elbow extension, thoracic extension mobility, and core/postural control to maintain upright torso while the shoulders move through large ranges.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: flexion / abduction / horizontal abduction-adduction and external/internal rotation

notes: Primarily a mobility/scapular-control drill. Variation in grip width and band stiffness changes shoulder ROM demands. When performed slowly with active retraction it emphasizes scapular 'pull' mechanics; performed passively or with external assistance it becomes more of a mobility/stretching exercise. Avoid if symptomatic shoulder impingement unless cleared.

exercise: Band face-pull (pause at full external rotation)
reasoning: Primary joint actions are scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction) and shoulder external rotation with concomitant shoulder horizontal abduction as the band is pulled toward the face. Elbow flexion accompanies the pull but is secondary. These actions occur primarily in the transverse plane. The pattern is a horizontal PULL because the movement withdraws the load toward the torso/face with scapular retraction; it also includes a rotational component at the glenohumeral joint (external rotation) so ROTATION is included. Stabilization demands include isometric trunk control and scapular stabilizers (lower/middle trap, serratus, rhomboids) to position the shoulder girdle and resist unwanted scapular motion.
notes: Pause at full external rotation increases load on the posterior rotator cuff and posterior deltoid. Ensure band is anchored at approximately face height, elbows driven laterally to maintain correct line of pull. Avoid excessive neck extension or scapular elevation; emphasize scapular retraction and downward rotation during return. Variations: single-arm face-pull (adds anti-rotation/stability demand).

reasoning: Primary movement is a stepping/locomotion pattern performed laterally/diagonally while maintaining a partial squat. The hips perform repeated abduction (frontal plane) with concurrent external rotation (transverse plane) to move the foot laterally against band resistance. The knees and hips remain in partial flexion to load the quadriceps and create a stable base (isometric squat posture) while the gluteus medius/minimus and TFL drive lateral stepping. Core/trunk muscles act isometrically to maintain upright posture and resist frontal/transverse plane collapse.
notes: Band placement (above knees vs ankles) alters resistance on gluteus medius vs TFL. Cue to avoid knee valgus and keep neutral spine. Can be performed laterally, diagonally (monster-walk), or reverse for variation.

reasoning: Primary movement is large-range glenohumeral flexion (raising the arms overhead) and the reverse (extension) through the sagittal plane, combined with transverse-plane humeral rotation and horizontal ab/adduction as the arms track from front to back. Scapulothoracic upward rotation and posterior tilt occur to allow overhead range. The band creates tension the shoulders work against during both concentric and eccentric portions. Stabilization demands include isometric elbow extension and active scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius) and rotator cuff control to preserve humeral head centration. Thoracic mobility/rotation facilitates the endpoint of the arc.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (infraspinatus, supraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: horizontal abduction/adduction (arm travels anterior to posterior)

notes: Primarily a shoulder mobility drill rather than a strength transfer exercise. Grip width and band tension alter demands (wider grip reduces needed shoulder rotation). Emphasize controlled scapular motion and rotator-cuff control; avoid forcing range into pain. Can be progressed to single-arm or performed with PVC for lower resistance.

reasoning: Primary movement is multi-planar glenohumeral circumduction (large arc of shoulder flexion → extension with horizontal ab/adduction and axial rotation) combined with scapulothoracic protraction/retraction and thoracic extension. The hands remain extended at the elbow while the shoulders move the implement over and behind the head—this is a rotational/mobility pattern of the shoulder girdle rather than a sagittal push or pull. Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles control humeral head translation while thoracic extensors and spinal mobility permit the path of motion; core and lats provide secondary stabilization against unwanted pelvis/trunk movement.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension with circumduction and axial rotation

notes: Grip width and implement stiffness change demands: wider grip increases shoulder external rotation/thoracic extension requirement; band vs stick adds variable tension. Avoid if painful—progress with narrower grips or perform scapular mobility first.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane, producing a pulling/arm-flexion movement. The biceps brachii (also a forearm supinator), brachialis and brachioradialis generate elbow flexion. Shoulders and scapulae act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm; wrists and grip muscles stabilize the bar. No purposeful rotational or carry components are involved unless performed asymmetrically or with intent to rotate.
notes: Strict barbell curl is a single-joint elbow-flexion (PULL) movement. Variations (cheat curls, incline curls, preacher curls, heavy momentum) change stabilization demands and may introduce shoulder or torso movement. Asymmetric loading or rotational intent would add ANTI_ROTATION/ROTATION patterns.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal/face-level pull: scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction) and shoulder horizontal abduction in the transverse plane, producing the pulling motion. Simultaneously there is active external rotation of the glenohumeral joint (rotation of the humerus) as the hands are drawn toward the face. Elbow flexion contributes secondarily. Core and trunk act isometrically to stabilize the torso during the band pull. Primary movers are the posterior shoulder and scapular retractors (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids, posterior deltoid) and the external rotators of the rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor).

joint_actions.action: horizontal abduction / extension (pulling the arms back toward the face)

notes: Typically taught as a horizontal pull with emphasis on external rotation for rotator cuff conditioning. Cue scapular retraction and avoid excessive loading or forward head; variations include single-arm band face pulls or different hand/rope grips to emphasize external rotation vs. posterior deltoid.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip extension in the sagittal plane with the torso/upper back supported and the feet fixed on the floor. The hips drive upward against the barbell load via concentric hip extension (gluteus maximus and hamstrings). Knees remain flexed (isometric) for most implementations and the lumbar spine/erector complex functions to stabilize and maintain a neutral trunk, preventing excessive spinal extension. Therefore the dominant pattern is a hip-dominant hinge rather than a squat, push, or carry.
notes: Barbell placement across the hips creates axial load but does not change the primary hip-extension hinge pattern. Variations: single-leg glute bridge introduces anti-rotation/unilateral stabilization demands; higher foot placement increases hamstring contribution, lower foot placement emphasizes gluteal drive. Avoid lumbar hyperextension; cue posterior pelvic tilt at top for safe mechanics.

reasoning: Primary movement occurs at the glenohumeral joint as the hands/bar translate anteriorly (shoulder flexion) in the sagittal plane — functionally analogous to a horizontal/anterior push of the hands away from the torso. The elbows remain largely extended (isometric) while the trunk must resist sagittal plane extension (anti‑extension) under a long lever; the core (rectus abdominis, obliques, transverse abdominis) and hip musculature act isometrically to prevent lumbar hyperextension. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower trapezius) control scapular protraction/repositioning during the reach. Because the provided pattern set does not include an explicit ANTI‑EXTENSION core category, the best match among available patterns is PUSH (sagittal plane anterior translation of the hands).
notes: This exercise is fundamentally an anti‑extension core challenge with anterior hand translation; because the available pattern list lacks an ANTI‑EXTENSION category, it is classified as PUSH (anterior/sagittal push of the hands). Variations: kneeling rollout (shorter lever, easier), standing rollout (long lever, higher core demand). Caution with lumbar control—avoid passive spinal extension/hyperextension. Use progression/regression by range of motion and assistance (banded returns).

exercise: Barbell Curls Lying Against An Incline
reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane (a pulling pattern). Performed on an incline bench the shoulders are placed into relative extension (increasing long-head biceps stretch) and act largely as a fixed/stabilized position while the elbows flex and extend to move the barbell. The biceps brachii (long head emphasized), brachialis and brachioradialis produce the concentric/eccentric elbow flexion. Scapular and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the shoulder girdle isometrically against the bench; core and thorax are passively stabilized by contact with the bench. Forearm supination contributes to biceps force production.
notes: Incline position emphasizes the biceps long head by increasing shoulder extension at start position and reduces momentum. Barbell provides bilateral, fixed-grip loading; using unilateral dumbbells increases anti-rotation demand. Keep elbows stable to maintain isolation.

reasoning: Primary joint action is shoulder flexion in the sagittal plane as the hands/bar are driven away from the torso (a pushing action). The lumbar spine moves into relative extension while the trunk musculature resists that extension (anti-extension/isometric core demand). Elbows remain nearly extended (isometric) and hips are largely fixed in a kneeling position. The movement is therefore best classified as a sagittal-plane pushing pattern (hands pushing the load away) with a dominant isometric anti-extension core requirement.
notes: This exercise is fundamentally an anti-extension core exercise but, given available pattern categories, it is classified as a PUSH because the hands drive the load forward (shoulder flexion and scapular protraction). Progressions include standing or single-arm variations; caution for lumbar hyperextension—maintain braced core and avoid excessive roll-out range if lacking core control.

reasoning: This is an isolation ankle plantarflexion exercise performed in a seated position. The primary joint action is concentric plantarflexion (ankle) in the sagittal plane. The knee is held in a flexed, relatively static position (which biases the soleus over the gastrocnemius), and the hips/spine act as stabilizers to maintain posture and support the load. Because the movement is limited to the ankle joint and does not involve hip or knee extension/flexion patterns, it does not map cleanly to the provided global movement patterns (squat/hinge/push/pull/lunge/locomotion/carry/rotation/anti-rotation).
notes: Seated position biases the soleus due to knee flexion. Typical execution places a barbell or pad across the thighs; machine seated calf raises follow the same pattern. This exercise is an isolation ankle movement and should be flagged for manual review if a movement-pattern assignment is required by a system that expects one of the standard multi-joint patterns.

reasoning: Primary dynamic action is sagittal-plane shoulder flexion as the hands/bar move away from the body (a horizontal/forward push of the hands). The trunk undergoes a controlled change in sagittal curvature but is primarily resisted isometrically by the anterior core (anti-extension). Elbows are held near full extension (isometric). Shoulders (anterior deltoid, pec minor/major to a lesser extent, serratus anterior for protraction) produce/guide the arm travel while rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis and obliques resist spinal extension and prevent lumbar hyperextension. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower traps) and lats assist stabilization of the shoulder girdle. Because the defining external movement is pushing the bar away in the sagittal plane, the movement best maps to the PUSH pattern with heavy anti-extension core demand (not an anti-rotation pattern).

joint_actions.action: flexion (humeral elevation/forward translation) and scapular protraction
resisted extension (anti-extension/isometric control of lumbar spine)

notes: Common progressions/variations include performing from knees (easier) to standing (harder). Emphasis is core anti-extension rather than traditional pressing strength; wrist/shoulder stress and lumbar control should be monitored. If elbows markedly flex during the exercise or a concentric press is performed, contribution of triceps/pecs increases.

reasoning: Performed prone on an incline bench lifting the barbell away from the body primarily by moving the humerus into horizontal abduction/extension (shoulder horizontal abduction) in the transverse plane — a pulling-type shoulder movement. Primary joint action is shoulder horizontal abduction/extension produced by posterior deltoid and scapular retractors (middle trapezius, rhomboids). Elbows remain slightly flexed and largely isometric to hold the implement; the thoracic spine and lumbar erectors maintain a neutral/stable trunk on the bench. Scapular retraction/elevation control from mid/lower traps and rhomboids is required for proper ROM and shoulder health.
notes: Name is somewhat ambiguous — interpretation assumes an incline prone rear-delt (reverse fly) style raise. If performed as an incline front raise (arm moves into shoulder flexion in the sagittal plane), primary pattern and muscle emphasis would shift (still a shoulder-dominant movement but different plane). Ensure scapular control and rotator cuff integrity when loading; single-arm or asymmetric variations add ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is scapular elevation (shoulder girdle elevation) in the frontal plane. The scapulothoracic articulation elevates via concentric contraction of the upper trapezius and levator scapulae; the glenohumeral joint remains relatively static with elbows extended or slightly flexed (no significant shoulder flexion/abduction). The spine, hips and knees act isometrically to stabilize the torso while the shoulder girdle performs the elevation. Therefore the dominant pattern is a vertical pull (scapular/shoulder-girdle pull).
notes: Variations (dumbbell, trap bar) do not change primary pattern. Combining with upright row adds glenohumeral abduction/elevation and may introduce additional shoulder movement. Avoid excessive neck extension; cue scapular motion (elevation) rather than shrugging with neck muscles.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: concentric shoulder elevation (primarily shoulder flexion/vertical abduction to bring the bar overhead) with simultaneous elbow extension in the sagittal plane. Scapulothoracic upward rotation (upper trapezius, serratus anterior) is required to position the glenoid. The spine and core act isometrically to resist extension and maintain a neutral thoracic/lumbar position; hips/knees/ankles are typically braced isometrically in a strict press (unless performing a push press). Primary movers are the anterior deltoid and lateral deltoid producing shoulder elevation and the triceps producing elbow extension; scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the shoulder complex throughout the range.

joint_actions.action: isometric extension / core stabilization (resist excessive extension and maintain neutral posture)
isometric stabilization (minimal/no sagittal movement in strict press)
isometric stabilization (minimal/no sagittal movement in strict press)

notes: Variations: strict seated/standing military press remains a pure vertical PUSH; push press adds hip/knee extension (becomes PUSH + HINGE/LEG DRIVE). Behind-the-neck press changes scapular mechanics and may increase shoulder impingement risk. Grip width and torso lean alter relative contributions of anterior deltoid vs. clavicular pec.

reasoning: Primary motion is lateral flexion of the spine (frontal plane) — the trunk bends laterally toward the loaded side. The spine (lumbar) is the primary moving joint producing lateral flexion; the shoulders/arms hold the barbell isometrically to load the trunk. Hips, knees and ankles act primarily as isometric stabilizers to maintain upright stance. Muscles producing the movement are ipsilateral quadratus lumborum and the ipsilateral internal/external obliques with contribution from erector spinae; contralateral spinal muscles act eccentrically to control the return. Shoulder girdle and lower-limb muscles work isometrically for load support and balance.
notes: Barbell Side Bend is primarily a trunk lateral-flexion/oblique-loading exercise. If the load is held asymmetrically (one-sided load) or performed as a marching carry variant, include ANTI_ROTATION and/or CARRY. Use caution with heavy loading on the lumbar spine; consider alternatives (side plank, Pallof press) for safer lateral core training.

reasoning: Primary action is scapular elevation (shrug) performed with the barbell behind the torso. The movement is produced by concentric shortening of the upper trapezius and levator scapulae causing superior translation (elevation) of the scapulae with some accompanying upward rotation in the frontal plane. The shoulders and scapulothoracic articulation are the primary movers; the elbows are held isometrically to support the load and the cervical/spinal extensors may contribute minimally. Stabilization demands include scapular stabilizers (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids, serratus anterior) to control scapular position, grip/forearm muscles to hold the bar, and the trunk to maintain an upright posture. The behind-the-back bar position alters shoulder/scapular geometry (may change ROM and increase demand on scapular elevators and cervical stabilizers) but does not change the fundamental pull/scapular-elevation pattern.
notes: Behind-the-back placement changes shoulder/scapular mechanics and may reduce comfort or ROM for some lifters; maintain neutral spine and avoid excessive load if cervical symptoms present. Variation: dumbbell shrugs or behind-neck shrugs alter scapular kinematics and grip demands.

reasoning: Primary action is unilateral, closed-chain hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane as the lead leg pushes the body up onto an elevated surface. Ankle plantarflexion often contributes in the final phase. The movement is functionally a single-leg stepping pattern (LUNGE pattern) but shares the vertical displacement mechanics of a SQUAT when viewed bilaterally. Primary movers (gluteus maximus, quadriceps) generate concentric extension; gluteus medius and adductors stabilize the pelvis in the frontal plane; core and erector spinae isometrically stabilize the trunk while bearing a barbell. Balance and single-leg stability demands are substantial, and bar position (back/front) alters trunk lean but does not change the primary sagittal hip/knee extension pattern.
notes: Variations: box height, step cadence, and bar position (high-bar vs low-bar) change ROM and trunk lean. When performed with bilateral simultaneous stepping (rare) it trends more toward SQUAT mechanics; asymmetric/uneven loading introduces ANTI_ROTATION demands and would modify classification.

reasoning: This is a quadrupedal locomotion pattern performed while dragging a sled. Primary movement is locomotion: repeated hip and knee flexion/extension (sagittal plane) to drive alternating steps/crawling. The sled drag imposes a horizontal rearward resistance that must be overcome primarily by posterior chain hip extension and, depending on attachment, by upper-body pulling/scapular control—so a horizontal pull component is present. Shoulders and scapulae produce/accept load through protraction/retraction and isometric support while the core resists spine flexion/rotation to maintain trunk alignment.

joint_actions.action: alternating flexion and extension (propulsion via hip extension)
loaded flexion with repeated protraction/retraction for hand placement and force transfer to ground/strap
partial flexion/extension with periods of isometric support while weight-bearing
isometric trunk stabilization (resist flexion and rotation from sled load)

notes: If the sled is pulled by a harness at the hips, emphasis shifts to hip extensors (LOC + PULL via hips). If pulled by handles/arms, increased upper-body pulling and scapular control occur. Asymmetry or unilateral dragging variations would add ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: Primary action is active thoracic spine rotation in the transverse plane as the upper torso/arm opens away from the start position. The shoulder undergoes transverse-plane horizontal abduction/extension as the arm moves posteriorly while the elbow may be flexed to hold the thumb. Primary movers for the rotation are the thoracic paraspinals and segmental rotators (multifidus) together with the obliques producing rotational torque; the posterior shoulder musculature and rotator cuff control the humeral movement while scapular retractors/upward rotators stabilize the shoulder blade. Stabilization requirements include isometric control of the lumbar spine and pelvis (to localize motion to the thoracic spine) and scapular stability to allow controlled shoulder opening.
notes: Mobility/stretch drill emphasizing thoracic rotation. Variations include knees bent/stacked (side-lying) or half-kneeling/standing; cue to isolate rotation to thoracic spine and avoid compensatory lumbar rotation. Use caution with acute shoulder or low-back pathology.

reasoning: Primary movement is repetitive shoulder-driven oscillation (alternating shoulder flexion and extension) producing waves/slams on the rope — functionally an upper-body pulling/action against the rope's inertia with substantial concentric/eccentric control. The shoulders (deltoids, lats) and scapular muscles produce the primary up/down/drive actions in the sagittal plane; the elbows perform small flexion/extension adjustments. The alternating bilateral arm actions produce torsional forces on the trunk that the core (obliques, transverse abdominis, erector spinae) resists isometrically (anti-rotation) in the transverse plane. Lower body (hips/knees) commonly remain in a semi-flexed athletic stance providing isometric support and force transfer. Slams or heavy two-arm patterns can increase hip extension contribution and transient sagittal power, but the dominant pattern remains upper-body pull-style oscillation with anti-rotational core stabilization.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion (athletic stance) / occasional extension during slams

notes: Variations change emphasis: double-arm vertical slams add more hip/knee drive (transient HINGE-like power) and can increase sagittal trunk flexion; heavy asymmetric patterns or single-arm rope work increase anti-rotation demand. Technique (standing vs. kneeling) alters lower-limb involvement.

reasoning: Primary task is loaded walking: repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane producing locomotion while holding a symmetric anterior load. The anterior-held load creates an anterior flexion moment on the spine that must be resisted isometrically (anti-extension) and the gait cycle (single-leg stance phases) introduces transverse-plane torques that the core (obliques, transverse abdominis) and hip stabilizers resist (anti-rotation). The shoulders and elbows are primarily isometric to maintain the hug position and scapular stabilizers prevent load migration.

joint_actions.action: resists flexion and resists axial rotation (anti-rotation/anti-flexion, isometric)

notes: Symmetric anterior load classifies it primarily as a CARRY; anti-rotation is included because single-leg stance phases of gait create transverse-plane moments requiring core/hip stabilization. Variations (uneven load, single-arm hug) increase anti-rotation demand; heavier loads increase spinal extension (erector spinae) demand.

reasoning: The bear-hug hold is an isometric anterior load hold: the upper limbs are held in shoulder flexion/horizontal adduction and elbow flexion to clasp the object, while the trunk and lower limbs produce isometric stabilization to resist forward collapse. Primary joint actions are shoulder flexion and horizontal adduction (transverse/sagittal), elbow flexion (sagittal) to maintain the hold, and isometric spinal extension (sagittal) to resist the anterior moment. Hips, knees and ankles act isometrically to maintain upright posture and transfer load to the ground. Because the exercise is a static, anterior-loaded hold (a carry variation) the primary movement pattern is CARRY rather than a push/pull or hinge; rotation is generally minimal unless the load is asymmetric.
notes: If the hold is performed while walking it remains CARRY and may add ANTI_ROTATION demands if load is asymmetric or single-arm. Variations (offset load, single-arm hug) increase anti-rotation and unilateral lower-limb stabilization requirements. Seated or supported variations reduce lower-limb and spinal extension demand.

reasoning: Primary action is single‑leg stepping/stepping‑over (hip and knee flexion for swing, hip and knee extension for stance/drive) performed while carrying an anterior 'bear‑hug' load. This combines a loaded locomotor/carry task with single‑leg sagittal-plane extension typical of lunge/step patterns. The anterior load and single‑leg stance create transverse‑plane torque that the core must resist isometrically (anti‑rotation) and resist flexion. Upper body performs an isometric hug to secure the load. Stabilization demands include frontal‑plane hip control (glute med) and core anti‑rotation/anti‑extension to maintain torso position during the step over.
notes: Stepping height, load mass/position, and pace change relative contribution of lunge vs. carry demands. High box or heavy load increases single‑leg strength and core anti‑rotation demands; asymmetrical positioning of the load would further increase anti‑rotation requirements. Ensure progressive loading and single‑leg balance training to reduce lumbar strain.

reasoning: Primary action is an isometric anterior load hold: shoulders are held in flexion and horizontal adduction with elbows flexed to clamp the load to the chest; the spine and hips produce/isometrically resist sagittal-plane flexion (anti‑flexion) so the trunk remains upright. The movement is essentially a static anterior carry pattern (loaded anterior torso position) requiring upper‑body clamp strength (pectoralis/anterior deltoid/biceps) and substantial trunk and lower‑limb isometric stabilization to resist the anterior moment from the load.
notes: This classification treats the static hug as an anterior carry variant. If the bear-hug is performed while walking/marching, add ANTI_ROTATION when asymmetric gait or single-leg stance increases rotational demands. Asymmetric loading or unilateral hugging would also introduce pronounced anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion requirements.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are isometric/near-isometric: shoulders are held in flexion and adduction to clamp the sandbag to the chest, elbows in flexion to secure the load, and the spine is held in neutral with strong isometric extension/anti-flexion to resist the anterior moment created by the load. Lower limbs (hips/knees/ankles) provide an isometric support base. Because this is an anterior loaded hold, it functions as a loaded-carry pattern (static carry) and requires core anti-rotation/anti-flexion stabilization to keep the torso upright and resist rotational or flexion torques. Primary movers about the shoulders and elbows produce the holding action (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, biceps/forearms); core and posterior chain (erector spinae, obliques, glutes, quads) act isometrically to maintain posture and resist collapse or rotation.

joint_actions.action: flexion and adduction (isometric to clamp load)
isometric extension / anti-flexion (resists anterior flexion moment); anti-rotation demand present

notes: If performed while marching/walking, carry demands increase and dynamic gait actions (hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension) should be emphasized — classification remains CARRY + ANTI_ROTATION. Asymmetric or offset bear-hug variations increase anti-rotation demand. Static bilateral bear-hug primarily challenges anterior shoulder/arm isometrics and sagittal-plane core anti-flexion.

reasoning: Bench jump is a plyometric vertical propulsion movement driven primarily by concentric hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion (triple extension) in the sagittal plane. The takeoff mechanic is essentially a rapid squat/hip hinge-to-extension pattern producing vertical impulse; landing requires eccentric control of the same joints. Primary movers are the hip extensors and knee extensors with calf plantarflexors contributing to propulsion. Stabilization requires core isometric control (preventing excessive trunk flexion/extension) and frontal-plane hip stability on landing.
notes: Box/bench jump is a plyometric variant of a squat jump. Arms often contribute via shoulder/elbow motion to increase momentum (secondary). Emphasize landing mechanics and appropriate box height; frontal-plane hip control (glute medius) is important to reduce valgus on landing. Variations (single-leg, step-down) change pattern emphasis and stability demands.

reasoning: A bench sprint is a sprinting/plyometric locomotion pattern performed with feet contacting a bench (often short, rapid drive steps). Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: repeated hip extension (push-off) and hip flexion (swing), knee extension and flexion, and ankle plantarflexion (propulsion) and dorsiflexion (swing/landing). Arm swing produces shoulder sagittal-plane flexion/extension to assist cadence. The core and hip abductors/adductors provide frontal/transverse plane stabilization and resist rotation during single-leg support on a narrow surface. Primary movers produce force for forward propulsion while trunk/hip muscles stabilize for balance and efficient transfer of force.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (resist rotation and maintain posture)

notes: Variation in setup changes demands: narrow/raised bench increases frontal-plane stabilization and ankle/hip balance demands; single-leg or alternating-leg bench sprints increase unilateral load and anti-rotation demands. If hands are placed on the bench (inclined sprinting), upper body support reduces trunk shear but increases shoulder/arm isometrics.

reasoning: Primary action is an isometric anterior load hold: shoulders are held in flexion and horizontal adduction while elbows are flexed to 'hug' the load; the trunk resists flexion and rotational torque to maintain upright posture. Therefore the dominant pattern is a front-loaded carry (isometric carry/anchor). Because an anterior load creates potential rotational moments (and many strongman anchors are offset or require resisting sway), the core must produce anti-rotation/isometric stabilization as a secondary pattern. Scapular stabilizers and forearms maintain grip, and lower-limb extensors provide postural support.
notes: If performed while walking/marching, the classification remains CARRY but anti-rotation demand increases; if load is markedly asymmetric or anchored off-center, ANTI_ROTATION becomes primary. This is primarily an isometric anterior-carry pattern emphasizing trunk and scapular stabilization rather than concentric movement.

reasoning: This is a loaded-marching pattern with an anterior (bear-hug) load held at the chest. Primary movement is repeated single-leg locomotion (hip and knee flexion/extension, ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion) in the sagittal plane while maintaining an isometric anterior hold. The anterior load shifts center of mass forward and requires strong trunk bracing to prevent forward flexion and resist rotational forces during single-leg stance, producing anti-rotation demands. Upper-extremity joints maintain an isometric shoulder/elbow flexed/adducted position to secure the load.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension (alternating during swing/stance); frontal-plane stabilization (abduction control)
isometric anti-flexion and anti-rotation (resist forward flexion and transverse rotation)

notes: Anterior load increases trunk flexion moment — cueing to brace and maintain upright thorax improves carry. If loading is asymmetric or excessively offset, anti-rotation demand increases. Slow, high-step marching increases single-leg stabilization demands (gluteus medius/obliques).

exercise: Bent Over Dumbbell Rear Delt Raise With Head On Bench
reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder horizontal abduction (reverse fly) performed with the torso supported on a bench. The glenohumeral joint performs horizontal abduction in the transverse plane while the scapulothoracic joints perform scapular retraction/adduction. Elbows remain slightly flexed and mostly stable; the bench support minimizes demand on the hip and lumbar extensors so the movement is isolated to the shoulder and scapula. This is a posterior shoulder/scapular pulling pattern emphasizing the posterior deltoid and scapular retractors with rotator-cuff stabilization.

joint_actions.action: horizontal abduction (posterior elevation of the humerus)
isometric stabilization (neutral posture supported by bench)

notes: Bench-supported variation reduces hip/lower-back involvement compared with a standing bent-over reverse fly; this makes it a more isolated horizontal PULL for posterior deltoid and scapular retractors. If performed standing or bent over without support, additional anti-flexion/hip hinge and core stabilization demands would be present.

reasoning: Primary action is scapular retraction (= pulling the scapulae together) with a secondary glenohumeral horizontal abduction/external rotation to open the anterior chest. The movement is performed primarily in the transverse plane with a small amount of spinal extension in the sagittal plane for chest opening. Although performed as a stretch, the active component is a scapular adduction (retraction) pattern similar to a horizontal pull; pectoralis major/minor are lengthened while rhomboids and middle trapezius produce the retraction. Elbows/hands simply position the load and may be held in flexion isometrically for the stretch.
notes: Primarily a mobility/stretch exercise rather than a load-bearing pattern. Classed as PULL because the active component is scapular retraction (horizontal pull). Avoid or modify if painful with shoulder impingement; variations include hands clasped behind head, hands on elbows, or driving elbows back against a wall for a more passive stretch.

reasoning: Primary joint action is shoulder horizontal abduction (transverse plane) — the arm moves posteriorly/away from midline against the low-pulley load (a pulling action). Scapular retraction/upward rotation accompanies the shoulder motion. The torso is held in a hip-hinged, flexed position requiring isometric hip and trunk stabilization; if performed one‑arm, the asymmetric load creates a rotational moment that the core must resist (anti-rotation). Therefore the movement is primarily an upper-body pulling pattern with a secondary anti-rotation stabilization demand.
notes: If performed bilaterally with both cables, anti-rotation demand is reduced; if performed single-arm, emphasize bracing to resist trunk rotation. Ensure a stable hip hinge and neutral spine to isolate shoulder horizontal abduction and protect the low back.
